attributes.alt: Book cover for A Friend Like You by Andrea Schomburg and Barbara Röttgen. The cover shows a squirrel offering an acorn to a bird sitting on a tree branch.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
What are some ways we can make new friends?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Use appropriate tone of voice; Join in singing, rhyming, and word play.
Make connections between words and real life.
Try to use new words and grammar.
Initiate play and join a group in play.
Use different art materials for exploration and for sensory experience.
Use picture prompts to help children talk about things that friends do together.
Examples include share, comfort, play ball, blow bubbles, play on the playground, and sing.
How can we be a good friend to others?
What characters are friends in that book?
Pretend to be Squirrel and the bird from
. Act out something you remember from the book.
How many friends do you have? Can you write the number?
Draw a picture of something you like to do with your best friend. How would you describe it?
Can you use the materials in the center to make a sculpture for one of your friends?
What is the name of a good friend of yours? What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of their name? Can you write the letter?
Use blocks to make a model of something that you and your friend can play with.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder  to
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Use appropriate tone of voice; Join in singing, rhyming, and word play.
Make connections between words and real life.
Try to use new words and grammar.
Initiate play and join a group in play.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Use pictures to learn which children enjoy the same activities.
Encourage children to use what they learn to find friends to play with during independent centers and outside time.
How can we be a good friend to others?
Show a picture of two good friends in a book.
Act like Squirrel did when he first heard the bird singing.
Count all the things you like to  do with your friends. What is  the number?
Draw a picture of something you   remember from
Can you tell a story about it?
Make up a fun game for you and a friend to play together.
What is the first sound you hear in the word
? What letter makes that sound? Can you  write it?
Build models of some of the things you and your friends like.

attributes.alt: Book cover for A Friend Like You by Andrea Schomburg and Barbara Röttgen. The cover shows a squirrel offering an acorn to a bird sitting on a tree branch.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking the guiding question,
What are some things that friends like to do together?
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Use appropriate tone of voice; Join in singing, rhyming, and word play.
Make connections between words and real life.
Try to use new words and grammar.
Initiate play and join a group in play.
Use different art materials for exploration and for sensory experience.
Explore pictures of food with children and sort them into “delicious” and “not delicious” categories.
Help children understand that friends can have different likes and dislikes.
How can we be a good friend to others?
Would you want to be friends with the character from that book? Why or why not?
Use movements to show me how you would welcome a friend.
Think of three different ways you can make a new friend. Let’s count them.
Draw a picture for a friend who is having a bad day.
Paint a picture of a favorite memory you have with a friend.
What sound do you hear at the beginning of the word
What are you building? Can you build something that you can  use to play with a friend?

attributes.alt:
A chart with the title Thank You, Friend, showing three images of friends together and an email.
Images include:
•   Two boys dressed in similar hero costumes. The caption reads: Good friends like to do things together.
•   Two children smiling together. The caption reads: Good friends share and take turns.
•   Two girls sitting at a desk playing with blocks. The caption reads: Good friends do nice things for each other.
•   The email reads:
To: rico at mail dot com.
Subject: Thank you!
Dear Rico, Thank you for being a good friend to me. I like when we play superheroes. I think it’s nice when you take turns with me on the swings. You are so good at doing puzzles! I like when we read books together. I’m glad we are friends. From, Alisha.
Book cover for A Friend Like You by Andrea Schomburg and Barbara Röttgen. The cover shows a squirrel offering an acorn to a bird sitting on a tree branch.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about what children  have learned about friends, sing a song about friendship, and introduce vocabulary words
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
Use appropriate tone of voice; Join in singing, rhyming, and word play.
Make connections between words and real life.
Try to use new words and grammar.
Initiate play and join a group in play.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Help children to discuss and draw pictures about people they are thankful for.
Help them to create an “I am thankful for . . .” classroom display.
How can we be a good friend to others?
Why do you think the character in that book had so many friends?
Show me how good friends act with each other.
Find out how old some of your classmates are. Who is the oldest? Who is the youngest?
What would you write in an email to your friend?
Make a cover for your own “I Am Thankful for . . .” book. Draw some pictures of the things you are thankful for on the cover.
. What is the first sound you hear? Can you show me the letters that make that sound?
Build two houses out of blocks so you and a friend can live next door to each other.

attributes.alt: Book cover for A Friend Like You by Andrea Schomburg and Barbara Röttgen. The cover shows a squirrel offering an acorn to a bird sitting on a tree branch.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to have children do an activity and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking,
What do you think is the most important thing about being a good friend?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Use appropriate tone of voice; Join in singing, rhyming, and word play.
Make connections between words and real life.
Try to use new words and grammar
Initiate play and join a group in play.
Use different art materials for exploration and for sensory experience.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
“What is your favorite thing about having good friends?”
Save children’s writing/drawing to display next week.
How can we be a good friend to others?
If you wrote your own book about being a good friend, what would be in it?
With a friend, pretend to be two animal friends.
Sort the things you like about your friends into different categories.
Create a drawing called “The Greatest Friend in the World.” Draw a picture to go with  your story.
Work with some friends to create a group friendship mural.
. What sound do you hear at the beginning of the word?
Create a Friendship Circle using blocks. Friends can sit inside the circle and play together.
